official-title.#text:
To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to
		  enhance the reporting requirements pertaining to use of antimicrobial drugs in
		  food animals.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Delivering Antimicrobial Transparency
			 in Animals Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The

Antimicrobials are
			 of critical importance to public health and to the American economy.

Use of
			 antimicrobials, whether in human medicine or in agriculture, contributes to the
			 development and spread of antimicrobial resistance.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(FDA) indicate that approximately 80 percent of all
			 antimicrobials sold in the United States, over 29,000,000 pounds in 2009, were
			 sold for use in food animals.

text.#text: Data from the

A study published in September, 2012, in
			 Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
			 found that even low doses of antimicrobials in animal feed for short periods of
			 time increased the prevalence of the bacteria E. coli and the prevalence and
			 diversity of antimicrobial resistance genes in bacteria in pigs.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, requires producers of
			 drugs used in food animals to provide specified information annually to the FDA
			 on the sales and indications for use of such drugs.
, the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: public-law/110/316

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Animal Drug User Fee Amendments of 2008
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Animal Drug User Fee Amendments of 2008

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
under the Animal Drug User Fee Amendments Act of 2008
			 lacked sufficient details necessary to analyze trends in antimicrobial
			 resistance, such as information on actual drug use in specific food-producing
			 animal species.

text.#text:
A
			 September 2011 study by the Government Accountability Office found that the
			 data provided to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and the public with better information on the use
			 of antimicrobial drugs in animals used for food to—

text.#text: The purpose of this Act is to provide the

improve the understanding of the
			 relationship between antimicrobial drug use in animals used for food and
			 antimicrobial drug resistance in microbes in and on animals and humans;
			 and

identify interventions to prevent and
			 control such antimicrobial drug resistance.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and inserting the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act/s:512/ss:l/p:3

			 512(l) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act/s:512/ss:l

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that contains an antimicrobial active
				ingredient, the sponsor of the drug shall submit an annual report to the
				Secretary on the amount of each antimicrobial active ingredient in the drug
				that is sold or distributed for use in food-producing animals, including
				information on any distributor-labeled product.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act/s:512/ss:l/p:1

text.#text:
In the case of each new
				animal drug described in

Each report under this paragraph shall
				specify the amount of each antimicrobial active ingredient—

by container size, strength, and
				dosage form;

by quantities distributed to each
				State domestically and by quantities exported; and

by dosage form, including (for each dosage
				form) the known or estimated amounts of the antimicrobial active ingredient
				sold or distributed for use in each food-producing animal for which the new
				animal drug is approved, including a description of the methods used to
				determine or estimate the amounts.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in the case of
				animal feed in final formulation bearing or containing a new animal drug for
				which reporting is required under

the quantity of such feed sold or

for each such feed sold or

the number of individuals of the

the length of time over which the feed
				was intended to be provided to the animals and the dose of the active
				antimicrobial ingredient the animals were intended to receive.
